Eye

11.3 Anti-infective eye preparations

?General Guidance

	Most acute superficial eye infections can be treated topically.
	Systemic anti-infective agents may occasionally be required.


11.3.1 Antibacterials

General Guidance

	Chloramphenicol has a broad spectrum of activity and is the drug choice for superficial eye infections. The drug is generally well tolerated, concerns regarding aplastic anaemia is mainly extrapolated from oral data and therefore unlikely to be relevant.
	Recently several 4-quinolone eye drop preparations have become available. It would seem prudent to reserve these antibiotics for cases which specifically require these agents.
	Fusidic acid is useful for staphylococcal infections.
	Many antibiotic preparations also incorporate a corticosteroid, these products should NOT be used unless the patient is under specialist supervision. They should not be used for undiagnosed ?red eye? which may be due to herpes simplex virus.

	?Recommended drugs
	?
????????Chloramphenicol eye drops or eye ointment
????????Fusidic acid (Fucithalmic) eye drops





11.4 Corticosteroids and other anti-inflammatory preparations


11.4.1 Corticosteroids

General Guidance

	Corticosteroids administered locally or systemically have an important role to play in the treatment of anterior segment inflammation.
	Topical corticosteroids should usually only be used under expert supervision.
	Use in ?red eye? with unconfirmed diagnosis is potentially hazardous since this may be due to herpes simplex virus infection in which case corticosteroid would aggravate the condition and could result in corneal ulceration. Bacterial, fungal and amoebic causes pose similar risks.
	Prolonged use may lead to cataract formation.
	A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory eye drop preparation may be useful if the intraocular pressure is raised.

	?Recommended drugs???????
	?
????????Betamethasone
????????Dexamethasone
????????Prednisolone
????????Diclofenac eye drops



11.4.2 Allergic conjunctivitis

General guidance

	Many of these products are available over-the-counter from community pharmacies.
	In hay fever, start using the products 2-3 weeks before symptoms appear.

	?Recommended drugs?
	?
?1st line????????Sodium cromoglycate eye drops
?2nd line???????Lodoxamide

?For acute symptom only
??????????????????? Antazoline (Otrivine-Antistin)
????????




11.5 Mydriatics and cycloplegics

?General Guidance

	Antimuscarinics vary in potency and duration of action.
	Darkly pigmented iris is more resistance to pupillary dilation and caution should be exercised to avoid over dosage.
	Mydriasis may precipitate acute angle-closure glaucoma. Those at special risk are usually aged over 60 years and hypermetropic (long-sighted)
	Patients should be warned not to drive for 1-2 hours after mydriasis.
	Cyclopentolate 0.5% or 1% is useful for refraction in children.

	?Recommended drugs
	?
????????Atropine eye drops
????????Tropicamide (for eye examinations)



11.6 Treatment of glaucoma

General Guidance

	The rise in intraocular pressure almost always due to reduction in outflow of aqueous humour, the inflow remaining constant.
	The most common form of glaucoma is primary open angle glaucoma, where a topical beta-blocker is considered the first line therapy. Other drugs such as dorzolamide, pilocarpine or brimonidine may be added if the glaucoma is not well enough controlled.
	Latanoprost is indicated for open angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension in patients unresponsive to other therapy, or when they are contra-indicated.
	Miotics such as pilocarpine are used in the management of closed angle glaucoma.
	A combination of products such as Cosopt may be used for patient?s convenience if both drugs are required.

	?Recommended drugs
	?
?Beta blocker
????????Timolol topical
?Prostaglandin
????????Latanoprost topical
????????Bimatoprost topical
????????Travaprost topical
????????Tafluprost topical
????????Lantanoprost with timolol topical
????????Bimatorpost with timolol topical
????????Travaprost with timolol topical?
?Sympathomimetics
????????Brimonidine topical
?Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors and systemic drugs
????????Acetazolamide oral
????????Brinzolamide topical
????????Brinzolamide with timolol (Azarga) topical
????????Dorzolamide topical
?Miotics
????????Pilocarpine topical
?Combination products
????????Xalacom (latanoprost + timolol)
????????Combigan (brimonidine + timolol)
?

?
	?AMMC Non-Approved Drugs
	?
?Bimatoprost 0.01% (Lumigan)
?



11.7 Local anaesthetics

?General Guidance

	Local anaesthetics should only be used on the recommendation of a specialist.
	Local anaesthetics should not be used for the management of ocular symptoms.



11.8 Miscellaneous opthalmic preparations


11.8.1 Tear deficiency, ocular lubricants, and astringents





General Guidance

Click here to see suggested dry eye treatment pathway based on severity

	Chronic soreness of the eyes associated with reduced or abnormal tear secretion will often respond to tear replacement therapy.
	The severity of the condition, frequency of administration and patient preference often guides product choice.
	Hypromellose is the most common agent and should be considered as first line. However, it may require hourly administration. Additions of polymers may prolong its duration of action (e.g. Tears Naturale ?).
	Polyvinyl alcohol increases the persistence of the tear film and is useful if the natural mucin layer across the eye is reduced.
	Eye ointments may be useful to lubricate the eye surface. However, they may cause temporary visual disturbance, but may be especially useful to provide nighttime relief.

	?Recommended drugs
	? 
?Short duration of action
????????Hypromellose eye drops
?Long duration of action
????????Viscotears
?Eye ointment
????????Simple eye drops





	KEY
	Drug Traffic Light Key:	Green	Formulary choice
	?	Amber	Restricted use, see local guidelines
	?	Red	Specialist use/initiation
	Relative Costs (where indicated): 	?????	high
	?	???	moderate
	?	?	low

title: Thames Valley Priorities Committees
text:
Thames Valley Priorities CommitteesSouth Central Priorities Committees 
(Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, Berkshire East, Berkshire West, Buckinghamshire PCTs) 
 
Policy Statement 3: Bendamustine in the treatment of relapsed or refractory 
non-Hodgkin?s lymphoma 
 
Date of issue:   April 2010 
  
The Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, Berkshire & Buckinghamshire Priorities Committee has 
considered the evidence for the use of Bendamustine in the treatment of relapsed or 
refractory non-Hodgkin?s lymphoma and recommends that it should be LOW PRIORITY, 
because of lack of evidence of clinical effectiveness.  
 
The non-Hodgkin?s lymphomas (NHL) are a clinically and biologically diverse group of malignant 
diseases where the proliferating cell type is lymphoid. Some forms of NHL are indolent (low-
grade) where life-expectancy is usually in the order of years but there is little prospect of cure; 
whereas others are more aggressive (high-grade) with shorter untreated life-expectancy (but 
paradoxically having some prospect of cure) and requiring much more intensive treatment. For 
most patients, treatment involves a number of different courses of chemotherapy leading to 
disease remissions or responses of variable duration.  
 
Bendamustine is an alkylating agent that has been in use in Eastern Europe for over 30 years, 
but only actively researched since the early 1990s. It appears to have little cross-resistance with 
other alkylating agents and therefore has a theoretical advantage in patients whose disease is 
already refractory to, or has relapsed following treatment with other alkylating agents.  
 
At the time of this review, bendamustine is not licensed for use in the UK, although it is being 
made available without cost on a compassionate basis.  
 
The evidence of clinical effectiveness for the use of bendamustine in relapsed or refractory NHL 
is limited by the lack of comparative studies. The small single arm non-randomised studies that 
have been identified did not even have matched historical controls. There is no published 
evidence for cost-effectiveness.  
 
Bendamustine is currently being scoped on the NICE work programme. It is not known whether 
it will proceed to a technology appraisal. 
NOTES: 
1. Exceptional circumstances may be considered where there is evidence of significant health impairment and there is also 
evidence of the intervention improving health status. 
2. This policy will be reviewed in the light of new evidence or guidance from NICE.
Thames Valley Priorities Committees

title: Microsoft Word - Enc O Paper 1 PEC Minutes 1 September 2009.doc
text:
Microsoft Word - Enc O Paper 1 PEC Minutes 1 September 2009.doc                                                                                                               
 
 
PROFESSIONAL EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE (PEC) 
 
MINUTES OF MEETING HELD ON 1 SEPTEMBER 2009 
 
Present: Paul Bingham, Consultant in Public Health 
 Peter Coleman, General Practitioner  
Sheila Paul, Chief Operating Officer 
Jenifer Smith (Chair), Director of Public Health and Chief Medical Adviser 
Peter Taylor, Non-Executive Director 
George Thomson, General Practitioner  
Gary Warner, Community Pharmacist 
 
Not Present: Robin Beal, Clinical Director of Access and Assessment  
Kevin Flynn, Chief Executive 
Mark Howell, Acting Director of Community Services IWC 
Gill Vickers, Interim Head of Adult Social Care 
Peter Close, Consultant Radiologist 
 
In Attendance: Eleanor Roddick, Assistant Director of Commissioning (Acute) 
 Sarah Stringer, Sexual Health Promotion Co-ordinator 
For 5.1 ? Teenage Pregnancy 
Paula Friend, and 2 colleagues for 5.4 ? Southampton NHS Treatment Centre ? 
Care UK 
Minuted by: Julie Benson, PA to Jenifer Smith 
 
Apologies: Carol Alstrom, Director of Infection Prevention and Control & Chief Nurse 
 Ma?en Al-Mrayat, Clinical Director of Medical Services 
Helen Shields, Director of Commissioning 
 
 
Key Issues to be reported to the PCT Board 
09/93 Child Health Computer 
09/100 Low Priority Interventions Policy Statements 
 42 - Polysomnography in the Investigation of children with sleep-related disorders
 43 - Rituximab therapy for refractory autoimmune haemolytic anaemia or idiopathic
thrombocytopenic purpura 
 
  Key Issues to be reported to Integrated Governance Committee 
  
 
  Action 
09/89 DECLARATIONS OF INTERESTS  
 There were none.  
   
09/90 MINUTES OF THE PREVIOUS MEETING HELD ON 7 JULY 2009  
th
 The Minutes of the meeting held on 7 July 2009 were approved as a correct  
record. 
   
09/91 MATTERS ARISING FROM THE MEETING HELD ON 7 JULY 2009  
 There were none.  
 
   
09/92 TEENAGE PREGNANCY AND SEXUAL HEALTH  
 Sarah Stringer presented the key findings of the Brook Consultation.  
PEC was informed that teenage pregnancy was a social problem not a medical 
one. 
? A Strategic teenage pregnancy steering group to be set up which should 
ensure the development of a clear strategy for service provision and 
Isle of Wight Primary Care Trust 
Professional Executive Committee  1 September 2009                                                                                                                
 
support. 
? An outreach contraceptive nurse is now in post. 
? There has been a drop in under 16s opting for termination. 
? There are 4 under 25 clinics now set up. 
? Chlamydia screening rates need to improve. 
? Where practices have a named lead the results are improved. 
? Drop in at college every week in an effort to catch the young people for 
Chlamydia screening. 
 
The Professional Executive Committee received the report on Teenage 
Pregnancy. 
   
09/93 IMMUNISATION AND VACCINATION ACTION PLAN  
 Paul Bingham presented the Immunisation and Vaccination Action Plan needed as  
this is now on the risk register there are issues around girls not wanting to be  
vaccinated by School Nurses so would need to be immunised by their GP practice.  
  
HPV Catch up was poor.  One school was refusing to give out any information of  
vaccination and it was suggested that the PCT could use its powers to go to the  
Education Department of the Council.  It was also suggested that information could  
be cascaded through faith groups.  
  
It was suggested that education was important giving a more positive view on  
immunisation at the ante natal stage.  
  
Seasonal Flu H1N1 vaccinations were discussed and the use of community  
pharmacies as vaccinators.  It was suggested that the update of seasonal flu  
would be greater this year.  
  
Issues with the Child Health computer have not been resolved.  Greater clarity is  
needed on what the information flows are, where the process is defective, and who  
is taking this forward.  
  
An update is to be brought to the next PEC meeting.  PB 
 
   
09/94 HAMPSHIRE DATA REPOSITORY  
 JS presented to PEC the paper on the Hampshire Data Repository.  There are  
three main options to consider:  
  
? Extraction of data from GP and hospital systems on a regular basis  
 
(possibly using Miquest queries) and direct importation to the analytical 
database, bypassing the clinical HHR.  
 
? Extraction from the GP systems daily to the clinical HHR with the normal 
 
Graphnet extract, but with a facility for practices who do not want their 
 
patient data to be visible in the clinical HHR to put all of their records into 
 
quarantine.  This prevents access to the records, but permits their including 
 
in a pseudonymised form in the analysis database. 
 
? Extraction from the GP systems daily to the Clinical HHR with the normal 
 
Graphnet extract, but without the facility to put all patients from specific 
 
practices into quarantine. 
 
 
 
It was agreed that MPC would be the forum for this and it should go to the next 
 
meeting in October.  It was suggested that Hugh Sanderson and/or his colleagues 
JS 
should attend a future meeting.  JS to liaise with PC. 
 
 
 
09/95 SOUTHAMPTON NHS TREATMENT CENTRE 
 Paula Friend and two colleagues from Southampton NHS Treatment Centre (Care  
Isle of Wight Primary Care Trust 
Professional Executive Committee  1 September 2009                                                                                                                
 
UK) attended the meeting to inform PEC about the Services that the Treatment 
Centre offered.  Their objective was to provide a shorter waiting time and ensure 
that patients see everybody handling their care at one appointment slot.  PEC was 
informed that they have contracts with 4 PCTs and IOW was a small percentage of 
that contract.  Care UK were now looking at ways that they could help users from 
the Island to use the services and one way they are now looking at is to pay fares 
for the patient and the helper. 
 
There was discussions and it was felt that: 
? Patients would like the names of clinicians 
? GPs would like a brochure for surgeries setting out specialities how to 
contact the centre and names of surgeons. 
? A detailed information pack is in the process of being drafted. 
 
George Thomson agreed to be a link with the Centre. 
   
09/96 DVT TREATMENT PATHWAYS  
 Robin Beal and Ma?en Al-Mrayat are still to discuss the new National Policy. Peter RB/ 
Coleman requested that an agreed local pathway is urgently needed. MAM 
   
09/97 WCC ? PROCESS FOR 2009  
 JS informed the meeting that this year?s guidance is more challenging and more  
detailed.  The Strategy is to be delivered in early January.  
  
A meeting to clarify priorities will be held at the end of September.  
 
   
09/98 JSNA - UPDATE  
 PB updated the meeting that data collection was already computerised and that  
data would be published on the website.  
 
   
09/99 SHIP AND CATEGORY MANAGEMENT - UPDATE  
 Eleanor Roddick gave an update on the SHIP Category Management (CM) &  
Provider Relationship Management (PRM) proposals.  The agreed pathways are 
Stroke, Dementia, ENT, Cancer and Dentistry at a collaborative level which map in 
general to the PCTs Transforming Community Services priorities; Stroke, 
Dementia, End of Life Dentistry and CAMHS.  A Business Case is being prepared 
for both the CM and PRM which will be presented at the SHIP board on 3rd 
September setting out how the collaborative arrangements will operate. 
 
   
09/100 POLICY STATEMENTS FOR LOW PRIORITY INTERVENTIONS  
 PS42 ? Polysomnography in the investigation of children with sleep-related  
disorders 
There was discussion regarding the Policy Statement and it was agreed that if 
people did present with the conditions listed they would be investigated, just not 
referred for polysomnography. 
 
PS43 ? Rituximab therapy for refractory autoimmune haemolytic anaemia or 
idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura 
 
The Professional Executive Committee received the Policy Statements for 
Low Priority Interventions and recommended them to the Board. 
   
09/101 SUSTAINABILITY UPDATE  
 The work of the Group has moved into a new phase where each of the eight  
workstreams agreed previously are now being led by one or more clinicians. The 
process over the next two weeks will be for each of those leaders to ascertain: 
Isle of Wight Primary Care Trust 
Professional Executive Committee  1 September 2009                                                                                                                
 
? The Opportunity to Change through policy imperatives, key resource 
availability, good exemplars elsewhere, new design or technologies now 
available 
? Need for Improvement because of patient access, efficiency, quality, 
capacity, service range or policy imperative 
? The Impact upon patient levels, their carers, the cost, equity, quality, 
safety, capacity and range of services. 
? The Ease of Achievement by precedent, complexity, policy, public 
perception and other stakeholder impacts. 
 
In order to make this a swift process and also to scope out not just those streams 
that will be impacted but also those other streams that will impact upon them, each 
will meet with the team for a one-to-one and then reflect back to the group as a 
whole at the next meeting, once it is all collated into a whole. 
 
  
09/102 MATTERS ARISING FROM MINUTES OF MEETINGS 
th
Commissioning Board ? 14 July 2009  
 
st
 Service Delivery Board ? 21 July 2009  
th nd
Clinical Design Group ? 8 and 22 July 2009 
  
th
 Integrated Governance Committee ? 8 July 2009  
th
Primary Care Prescribing Committee ? 19 May 2009 
  
rd
 IOW Drugs Advisory Committee ? 3 July 2009  
th
 Medical Practitioners Committee ? 17 May 2009  
th
 Hampshire and IOW Priorities Committee ? 8 May 2009  
th
Nursing and Midwifery Board ? 8 July 2009 
  
   
Sheila Paul mentioned the two business cases to come from Service Delivery 
Board as being IV Antibiotics at Home and Heart at Home.  There being no other 
comments on any of the Minutes. 
   
09/103 ANY OTHER BUSINESS  
  
? Sequential Cochlear Implantation ? After discussion it was decided that this 
was not correct process.  If there are any comments on the document they are  
 
to be sent to JS.  It was felt that the document should go to the HIOW Priorities 
Committee for consideration.  
 
? JS informed the committee that a Medical Director had been appointed. 
 
? It was agreed that the form used for oxygen request was not easy to use and 
GT 
GT was to invite our oxygen supplier to talk at the next MPC meeting. 
   
09/104 DATE AND TIME OF NEXT MEETING  
th
Tuesday 6 October 2009 at 0830 in the Large Meetings Room, South Block, 
St Mary?s Hospital. 
 
Isle of Wight Primary Care Trust 
Professional Executive Committee  1 September 2009                                                                                                                
 
 
PROFESSIONAL EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE (PEC) 
 
MINUTES OF MEETING HELD ON 6 OCTOBER 2009 
 
Present: Ma?en Al-Mrayat, Clinical Director of Medical Services 
 Robin Beal, Clinical Director of Access and Assessment  
Paul Bingham, Consultant in Public Health 
Peter Coleman, General Practitioner  
Helen Shields, Director of Commissioning 
Jenifer Smith (Chair), Director of Public Health and Chief Medical Adviser 
Peter Taylor, Non-Executive Director 
George Thomson, General Practitioner  
Gary Warner, Community Pharmacist 
 
Not Present: Mark Howell, Acting Director of Community Services IWC 
Gill Vickers, Interim Head of Adult Social Care 
Peter Close, Consultant Radiologist 
 
In Attendance: Martin Robinson, Interim Associate Director for Mental Health 
 Gillian Baker, Deputy Director of Commissioning 
Rachel McKernan, 
Joyce Wise,  
Minuted by: Julie Benson, PA to Jenifer Smith 
 
Apologies: Carol Alstrom, Director of Infection Prevention and Control & Chief Nurse 
 Kevin Flynn, Chief Executive 
Brian Maxton, Deputy Director of Finance 
Chris Palmer, Director of Finance and IM&T 
Sheila Paul, Chief Operating Officer 
 
 
Key Issues to be reported to the PCT Board 
  
  
  
  
 
  Key Issues to be reported to Integrated Governance Committee 
  
 
  Action 
09/105 DECLARATIONS OF INTERESTS  
 Gary Warner informed the meeting that flu vaccines had been supplied by  
Pinnacle Pharmacy. 
   
09/106 MINUTES OF THE PREVIOUS MEETING HELD ON 1 SEPTEMBER 2009  
st
 The Minutes of the meeting held on 1 September were approved as a correct  
record, with the amendment of the date. 
   
09/107 MATTERS ARISING FROM THE MEETING HELD ON 1 SEPTEMBER 2009  
 09/02  - Teenage Pregnancy and Sexual Health - George Thomson informed the  
meeting that he had made contact with Sarah Stringer and agreed to act as a link  
to GPs.  
09/03  - Immunisation and Vaccination (Child Health Computer Issues) - The  
child health computer identified children not registered with a GP.  Children of pre- 
school age having previously been registered with a Health Visitor moving on the  
Island, or to the mainland, and not registered with a GP are removed from the  
Health Visitors list.  More difficult getting immunisation and vaccination report.  
Isle of Wight Primary Care Trust 
Professional Executive Committee  1 September 2009                                                                                                                
 
09/94 ? Hampshire Data Repository - Jenifer Smith confirmed that she had  
spoken with Jenny Nash but still needed to make contact with Hugh Sanderson or  
his colleagues regarding attendance at future MPC meeting.  
09/95 ? Southampton NHS Treatment Centre - Peter Coleman confirmed that he  
would be visiting the Southampton NHS Treatment Centre.  
09/96 - DVT Treatment Pathways - Ma?en Al-Mrayat presented a draft proposal  
paper regarding Developing DVT Primary Care Pathway.  This was agreed to be a GB 
very useful basis on which to take forward commissioning the service. 
   
09/108 SHARED CARE AGREEMENTS  
 Gillian Honeywell presented the paper on Shared Care Agreements.  There was  
an ongoing issue with prescribing toxic drugs associated with some long term 
conditions.  The monitoring is the responsibility of secondary care, but lack of 
confidence with this process.  Gaps in monitoring were highlighted and it was 
agreed that it was key to get monitoring right.   Access to the consultant was 
necessary if the GP would not prescribe and this was not always convenient for 
the patient. 
 
It was agreed that Shared Care Agreements would go the next MPC meeting. 
   
09/109 IMMUNISATION AND VACCINATION - UPDATE  
 Paul Bingham gave an update on immunisation and vaccination.  If seasonal flu  
campaign goes well, Community Pharmacists could be used as vaccinators for 
other conditions.  An action plan will be drafted to address vital signs compliance.  
With regard to HPV appreciation was expressed to the School Nurses for the way 
in which matters had been handled after the unfortunate nationally reported child 
death. 
 
Seasonal Flu ? Community Pharmacists would be used as vaccinators.  Supplies 
of the vaccine being reduced.  Staff will be receiving a letter this week encouraging 
uptake. 
 
H1N1 ? each practice would receive their allotted supply shortly in order for the 
priority groups to be vaccinated.  The training of 10 vaccinators to support 
pharmacies and technicians will be progressed.  NHS staff would be vaccinated in 
a week. 
   
09/110 COMMISSIONING STRATEGY ? LONG TERM CONDITIONS  
 Gillian Baker spoke to the meeting on long term conditions.  It was stated that  
there was a need to categorise long term conditions as a priority with investment 
priorities to come in 2011/12.   
 
After discussion points raised were:- 
 
? The understanding of what constitutes long term conditions. 
? A patient understanding about their disease. 
? In 2011 a personal health care plan would be necessary. 
? The necessity for psychological support for long term conditions. 
? A review of district nursing skills mix would be necessary. 
   
09/111 SUSTAINABILITY PROGRAME - UPDATE 
 Gary Warner stated that work had been refreshed on the 8 workstreams and was  
ongoing. 
 
It was stated that engagement to date had been good. 
   
09/112 PUBLIC HEALTH PERFORMANCE REPORTS  
 Mental Health Promotion - Rachel McKernan addressed the meeting on Mental  
Health Promotion.  Occupational Therapy  have agreed to support Mindful Mums 
Isle of Wight Primary Care Trust 
Professional Executive Committee  1 September 2009                                                                                                                
 
for 3 months whilst an evaluation is being undertaken after the instigator of Mindful 
Mums left her post. 
 
The Get Moving Campaign was highlighted as a way for the mentally ill to help 
with their condition.  It was aimed at everyone either to help with their mental 
health condition or to try and prevent mental illness.  Various events were 
highlighted culminating in the Get Moving Walk on 7th November. 
 
Health Trainers ? Joyce Wise introduced the Health Trainers report to the 
meeting and highlighted recent success: 
 
? A Health Trainer Service work plan for 09/10 has been produced to include 
preliminary Key Performance indicators/review stages for the Health 
Trainers and formalisation of review processes with partner organisations. 
? Development of a final set of service documentation for use by Health 
Trainers (client and management process), which is almost complete. 
? Recording of HT data improved and record keeping clearer. 
? City & Guilds training now complete. 
? IOW has taken the lead regionally with planned development of a set of 
Quality Standard for Health Trainer Services. 
? Work has begun on the feasibility study of the Health Trainer role in Parish 
Councils. 
 
Challenges were highlighted: 
 
? Gaining more 1-1 clients as well as information giving and sign posting 
activity. 
? Getting key messages across i.e. exercise, healthy eating, smoking. 
 
Feedback was positive and confidence had improved. 
 
Public Health Development Lead ? Joyce Wise outlined the development of a e-
group setting out what was available. 
 
The publication of standards and developing a Public Health Workforce Strategy 
this was being developed alongside the existing Workforce Strategy. 
   
09/113 MATTERS ARISING FROM MINUTES OF MEETINGS  
th
 Commissioning Board ? 11 August 2009  
th
 Service Delivery Board ? 18 August 2009  
th th
 Clinical Design Group ? 26 August 2009 and 9 September 2009  
th
 Primary Care Prescribing Committee ? 19 May 2009  
th
 IOW Drugs Advisory Committee ? 4 September 2009  
rd
 Clinical Effectiveness Committee ? 3 September 2009  
th
 Medical Practitioners Committee ? 17 May 2009  
th
 Hampshire and IOW Priorities Committee ? 8 May 2009  
th
 Nursing and Midwifery Board ? 9 September 2009  
   
There were no matters arising. 
   
09/114 ANY OTHER BUSINESS  
 There was none.  
   
09/115 DATE AND TIME OF NEXT MEETING  
Tuesday 3 November 2009 at 0830 in the Large Meetings Room, South Block, 
St Mary?s Hospital. 
 
Isle of Wight Primary Care Trust 
Professional Executive Committee  1 September 2009

title: Carers Partnership Board
text:
Carers Partnership Board

Carers Partnership Board

Carers Representative
ROLE DESCRIPTION
?
Title: ????????????? Carers Representative

?

Tasks:
Attend Carers Partnership Board meetings

Representing Carers in appropriate forums by invitation or as determined by the Board

Read documents relating to policies and new development on Carers 

Participate constructively in meetings 

Attend other meetings as agreed 

Attend training and development as agreed 

?
Person Specification: 

Carers Representative must be a carer of a Waltham Forest resident or have been a carer of a Waltham Forest resident within the past two years.

Must be over 18 years of age and be caring or/have cared for someone over 18 years of age. (Mechanism for ensuring young carers views are considered and adequately represented will reviewed at future meetings)

Have good public speaking abilities, though these can also be developed

Be willing and able to participate in meetings by reading, listening, asking questions and making comments 

Have a willingness to learn about the consultation mechanisms for carers and users across Waltham Forest

Be able to chair meetings if asked to

Be able to prioritise work by listening to other people and identifying what is achievable

Be able to speak calmly and convincingly when under pressure

Be sensitive to other people?s feelings?
Be able to listen carefully and help other people clarify what they meant

Be aware that carers come from diverse backgrounds and have very different experience

?

Code of Conduct:? 

Respect other people?s point of view 

Respect confidentiality. This means not telling other people about  sensitive information if you have been asked not to

Want to make things better 

Prepare and participate 

?
The role offers you the opportunities to: 

Learn more about Health and Social Care

Develop experience of participation in meetings 

Develop representation and presentation skills 

Benefit from relevant training and development opportunities


Carers Representatives 8th May 2012
Carers Partnership Board

Consultation Report for the East of England Implementation Plan
Formal written consultation on the draft EEIP was launched on 8th April 2009 and ran until 3rd July 2009. title: eCAB is a weekly bulletin of health-related news, including guidance, publications and policy, that provides a selection of the most important items from the National Prescribing Centre's daily Current Awareness Bulletin (eCAB)
text:
eCAB is a weekly bulletin of health-related news, including guidance, publications and policy, that provides a selection of the most important items from the National Prescribing Centre's daily Current Awareness Bulletin (eCAB) 
 
 
 
Medicines Awareness Weekly 
   
 
 
Medicines evidence commentary 
 
Insulin glargine: no effect on cardiovascular outcomes in early type 2 diabetes 
 
 
The ORIGIN trial found that, compared with standard care, the early use of basal insulin 
glargine for a median of 6 years had no effect on cardiovascular outcomes in people with 
impaired fasting glucose, impaired glucose tolerance or early type 2 diabetes who also 
had cardiovascular risk factors. As perhaps expected, episodes of severe hypoglycaemia 
were more common in those receiving insulin glargine. This is consistent with current 
NICE guidance on type 2 diabetes which recommends using appropriate stepped care with 
patients to manage their diabetes, using NPH (isophane) insulin as first choice in those 
who require insulin. 
 
Click here to read this medicines evidence commentary in full

Medicines evidence commentary 
 
Insulin glargine: no effect on cardiovascular outcomes in early type 2 diabetes 
 
 
The ORIGIN trial found that, compared with standard care, the early use of basal insulin 
glargine for a median of 6 years had no effect on cardiovascular outcomes in people with 
impaired fasting glucose, impaired glucose tolerance or early type 2 diabetes who also 
had cardiovascular risk factors. As perhaps expected, episodes of severe hypoglycaemia 
were more common in those receiving insulin glargine. This is consistent with current 
NICE guidance on type 2 diabetes which recommends using appropriate stepped care with 
patients to manage their diabetes, using NPH (isophane) insulin as first choice in those 
who require insulin. 
 
Overview and current advice: 
The management of patients with type 2 diabetes is complex, requiring an individualised 
multifactorial approach. Cardiovascular disease is the most common cause of death in people 
with type 2 diabetes and treatments would ideally show a reduction in this risk. With regard to 
blood glucose control, NICE clinical guideline 87 on type 2 diabetes recommends metformin, a 
sulfonylurea and human NPH (isophane) insulin e.g. Insulatard, Humulin I or Insuman Basal as 
1
the preferred hypoglycaemic drugs . A long-acting insulin analogue can be considered as an 
alternative to human NPH (isophane) insulin in particular patients, such as those who require 
assistance from a carer or healthcare professional to administer their insulin injections, or those 
with problematic hypoglycaemia. 
The NICE Clinical Guideline for the management of type 2 diabetes is currently being updated 
although the publication date for this update is to be confirmed. 
 
New evidence: 
ORIGIN, a large randomised controlled trial (RCT), was carried out to see whether the long-acting 
insulin analogue, insulin glargine, has cardiovascular benefits over standard care in people with 
impaired fasting glucose, impaired glucose tolerance or early type 2 diabetes who also had 
2
cardiovascular risk factors . 12,537 people were randomised to basal insulin glargine or standard 
care for a median of 6.2 years. In the glargine group, patients added an evening injection to their 
glycaemic-control regimen and titrated the dose to achieve a fasting plasma glucose level of 5.3 
mmol/l or less. Patients in the standard care group were treated using clinical judgement, which 
involved minimal insulin use (0% insulin use at baseline, rising to 11.4% by year 7). 
 
ORIGIN found the early use of basal insulin glargine had no effect on cardiovascular outcomes 
compared with standard care. The rate of cardiovascular death, non-fatal myocardial infarction, or 
non-fatal stroke was 2.94 per 100 patient-years in the insulin glargine group and 2.85 per 100 
patient-years in the standard care group (hazard ratio [HR] 1.02, 95% confidence interval [CI] 0.94 to 1.11, p=0.63). Similarly, there was no benefit from insulin glargine on this composite 
outcome plus revascularisation or heart failure (HR 1.04, 95% CI 0.97 to 1.11); or on all-cause 
mortality (HR 0.98, 95% CI 0.90 to 1.08) or microvascular outcomes (HR 0.97, 95% CI 0.90 to 
1.05). Compared with standard care, insulin glargine also had no effect on any cancer (HR 1.00, 
95% CI 0.88 to 1.13) or death from cancer (HR 0.94, 95% 0.77 to 1.15). 
 
Insulin glargine did reduce the incidence of diabetes in patients with impaired fasting glucose or 
impaired glucose tolerance at baseline. However, it was also associated with weight gain and 
more episodes of hypoglycaemia. Patients in the glargine group gained a median of 1.6 kg and 
those in the standard care group lost a median of 0.5 kg during follow-up. The incidence of a first 
episode of severe hypoglycaemia was 1.00 per 100 patient-years with insulin glargine and 0.31 
per 100 patient-years with standard care (p<0.001). 
 
See the NHS Evidence topic page on type 2 diabetes for a general overview of the condition. The 
NICE Pathway: diabetes brings together all related NICE guidance and associated products on 
the condition in a set of interactive topic-based diagrams. 
 
 
Commentary provided by Dr George Oswald* MD FRCP, Consultant Physician, Princess 
Elizabeth Hospital, Guernsey: 
In this RCT, early use of basal insulin glargine had no effect on cardiovascular outcomes but did 
increase the incidence of severe hypoglycaemic episodes compared with standard care. Insulin 
glargine was not associated with an increase in cardiovascular risk. However, treatments for type 
2 diabetes would ideally show a reduction in cardiovascular risk, not simply an improvement in 
surrogate markers (e.g. HbA1c levels).  
  
One of the main limitations with this study was the early use of insulin, which is not recommended 
in UK guidelines. NICE clinical guideline 87 recommends metformin, then metformin plus a 
sulfonylurea if blood glucose control remains inadequate (HbA1c above 6.5% [48 mmol/mol] or 
other higher agreed level). Human NPH (isophane) insulin is then recommended as the preferred 
third-line option if a person is still markedly hyperglycaemic on dual therapy (HbA1c above 7.5% 
[59 mmol/mol] or other higher agreed level). In ORIGIN, insulin glargine was given to people very 
early in treatment; 12% of people did not yet have diabetes (but had impaired fasting glucose or 
impaired glucose tolerance) and 6% had a new diagnosis of diabetes. At baseline, the median 
HbA1c was just 6.4%, and 41% of participants were not yet using metformin, a sulfonylurea or 
other oral hypoglycaemic drug. 
 
The study is potentially useful for highlighting any differences between early insulin use and no 
insulin use, as a large difference in insulin therapy was maintained between groups. However, it 
was not designed to test intensive versus conventional blood glucose control, and there was 
actually little difference observed between the groups in terms of glycaemic control. At 2 years, 
median HbA1c levels were 6.0% with insulin glargine and 6.3% with standard care. At 6 years, 
these levels were 6.3% and 6.5%, respectively. 
 
The ORIGIN trial used insulin glargine, not NPH (isophane) insulin which is the preferred first-
choice insulin recommended by NICE. For most people with type 2 diabetes, long-acting insulin 
analogues, such as insulin glargine, offer no significant advantage over human NPH (isophane) 
3
insulin and are much more expensive . The main benefits of long-acting insulin analogues over 
NPH insulin relate to lower rates of hypoglycaemia, and once daily use. However, these potential 
3
benefits need to be balanced against their much higher costs . A health economic analysis by 
4
NICE found that the cost-effectiveness of long-acting insulin analogues was not favourable . The 
incremental cost per QALY (compared with conventional insulin) was greater than ?100,000 in all 
scenarios, and in some scenarios in excess of ?400,000. It is more cost-effective to target use of 
long-acting insulin analogues to those people with type 2 diabetes who would be most likely to 
benefit. Hence, NICE clinical guideline 87 recommends long-acting insulin analogues can be 
considered as an alternative to human NPH (isophane) insulin in particular patients, such as those who require assistance from a carer or healthcare professional to administer their insulin 
injections, or those with problematic hypoglycaemia. 
 
* Dr Oswald became a Fellow of the Royal College of Physicians in 1990, is on the Specialist 
Register of the GMC and is a member of the British Diabetes UKic Association, the Association of 
British Clinical Diabetologists Society, and the Wessex Diabetic Endocrine Association, and the 
Intensive Care Society. 
 
 
References 
 
1. Type 2 diabetes: the management of type 2 diabetes. NICE clinical guideline 87 (2009) 
2. The ORIGIN Trial Investigators (2012). Basal insulin and cardiovascular and other outcomes 
in dysglycaemia. N Engl J Med 367:319?28 
3. Implementing key therapeutic topics: 3, Type 2 diabetes. MeReC Bulletin Vol 22, No 5, March 
2012 
4. Type 2 diabetes: newer agents for blood glucose control in type 2 diabetes. NICE Short 
clinical guideline 87 (2009)

				Hydref 11, 2012 14:20, Diweddarwyd am 14:20

				
					
Mae miliynau o deuluoedd yn wynebu biliau tanwydd uwch yn dilyn adroddiadau bod Nwy Prydain am godi ei brisiau.

					
						Straeon Perthnasol

							Llong dancer yn cludo nwy ar ei ffordd i Sir Benfro
	Eira: Achub teulu oedd yn sownd ar eu fferm
	Croesawu ?ail-feddwl? cynyddu prisiau petrol
	Galw ar Nwy Prydain i roi arian yn ?l i gwsmeriaid
	Elw Centrica yn achosi dicter
	Biliau trydan uwch ? rhybudd Ofgem
	Tanwydd: ?Cystadleuaeth yn y farchnad yn gweithio?n dda?
	Undeb Rygbi Cymru am ostwng prisiau?r Chwe Gwlad
	Nwy ?drewllyd? o Ffrainc yn cyrraedd Lloegr


					
					Yn ?l adroddiadau heddiw, mae disgwyl i Nwy Prydain, sy?n darparu nwy a thrydan i 12 miliwn o gartrefi, gyhoeddi fory eu bod am gynyddu eu prisiau.

					Roedd llefarydd ar ran Nwy Prydain wedi gwrthod gwneud sylw am yr adroddiadau.

					Daw?r adroddiadau wrth i gwmni SSE godi ei brisiau 9% ??o ddydd Llun, gan effeithio 5 miliwn o gwsmeriaid trydan a 3.4 miliwn o gwsmeriaid nwy.

					Roedd Nwy Prydain wedi cynyddu biliau nwy 18% a biliau trydan 16% ym mis Awst 2011, gan roi?r bai ar gostau uwch, ond cafodd prisiau trydan eu gostwng 5% ym mis Ionawr.

		Black Country History is a searchable website which allows users to find information about documents, maps, photographs, art works, objects and more held by archives and museums services within the Black Country.


The eight partners involved in this website are:


Dudley Archives and Local History Service

Dudley Museums Service

Sandwell Community History and Archives Service

Walsall Local History Centre

title: Sciencebase Science News and Views
text:
Sciencebase Science News and Views





	home
	book
	archives
	about
	
	



















Mar 11, 2013 

Animated rock art

			Posted at 11:10 am by David Bradley 
			?
Some of the world?s oldest engravings of the human form ? prehistoric rock art from the Italian Alps ? have been brought to life. PITOTI is an innovative research project that applies insights from the new technologies of computer graphics to prehistoric pictures, specifically the rock art of Valcamonica, Italy, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. It brings to life some of the earliest human figures in European rock art ? some made from as early ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
Mar 8, 2013 

World Book Day Confusion

			Posted at 8:05 am by David Bradley 
			?
It hadn?t occurred to me that there might be more than one World Book Day. Apparently (thanks Bob O?Hara) we Brits celebrate and promote literacy on 7th March to get around school holidays, which is why yesterday all the kids trotting up to school were dressed as characters from their favourite books. Apparently, the UNESCO WBD is on 23rd April (St George?s Day and the date Cervantes died) and seems to be more about enforcing ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
Mar 7, 2013 

Molecular Logic

			Posted at 11:10 pm by David Bradley 
			?
I first wrote about the pioneering work of Prasanna de Silva ? AP to his friends and colleagues ? back in the early 1990s in publications such as New Scientist, Science and others. It really was pioneering, he and his team at Queen?s University Belfast were starting to find ways to build molecules, that could substitute for the logic functions usually the preserve of ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
 
Deceived Wisdom World Book Day Offer

			Posted at 6:02 pm by David Bradley 
			?
UPDATE: Offer has now expired, but still offering the e-version of my book at a great discounted price, just ?4.99

World Book Day Offer: To celebrate WBD ? 2013-03-06, I?ve made the e-version of Deceived Wisdom just 99p (about $1.50) for the day. You can buy it in PDF, mobi or ePub format for your computer, device or other e-reader from my publisher E&T through the Sciencebase site.

Click the Paypal button below to buy a copy ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
Mar 6, 2013 

Hawking, Sagan and Arthur C Clarke ? ?together?

			Posted at 5:42 pm by David Bradley 
			?
Stephen Hawking, Carl Sagan and Arthur C Clarke were brought together (Sagan via satellite link) in conversation to discuss life, the universe and everything back in 1988.

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
 
Missing Links for March 5th through March 6th

			Posted at 11:00 am by David Bradley 
			?
These are my missing links for March 5th through March 6th:

Minimalistic Posters Pay Tribute To Scientists And Their Discoveries ? DesignTAXI.com ? via TAXI Daily News http://www.designtaxi.com/news.rss

Volvo Cars Now Detect & Automatically Brake For Cyclists, Pedestrians ? DesignTAXI.com ? via TAXI Daily News http://www.designtaxi.com/news.rss

Researchers Create A ?Google Map? Of The Human Metabolism | Popular Science ? ?
